citation.article-title: Actinobacillus delphinicola sp. nov., a new member of the family Pasteurellaceae Pohl (1979) 1981 isolated from sea mammals.

p.s: Description of Actinobacillus delphinicola sp. nov.
Actinobacillus delphinicola (del.phi.ni'co.la. L. n. delphinus, dolphin; L. n. cola, dweller: M.L.n. delphinicola, dolphin dweller)
Cells are pleomorphic gram-negative rods.
They are nonmotile and facultatively anaerobic, but added CO2 is required for growth.
Colonies on CSBA incubated in an atmosphere containing 10% added CO2 at 37°C are circular, entire, low, convex, smooth, grey, and 0.75 to 1 mm in diameter after 24 h.
Nonhemolytic or weakly hemolytic.
Blood or serum enhances growth.
No growth occurs on MacConkey agar.
Growth occurs at 42°C but not at 22°C.
Catalase negative and oxidase positive.
Nitrates are reduced to nitrites.
Nitrite is not reduced.

Acid is produced from glucose and mannose but not from adonitol, dulcitol, galactose, inositol, inulin, lactose, maltose, melibiose, raffinose, rhamnose, salicin, sorbitol, sucrose, trehalose, and xylose.
Voges-Proskauer positive.
Urease, H2S, and indole negative.

Alkaline phosphatase, esterase-lipase, leucine arylamidase, and acid phosphatase are produced in large amounts, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase is produced, usually in large amounts, and esterase is produced in lesser amounts when the API ZYM system is used.
Arginine may be hydrolyzed by some strains.
Some strains decarboxylate ornithine and/or lysine.
Isolated from cetaceans.
The type strain is strain NCTC 12870 (= M906/93).
The description of the type strain corresponds to that of the species except that the type strain is ornithine decarboxylase positive and arginine dihydrolase and lysine decarboxylase negative.
